name: Slovakia
partner: Central European Institute of Asian Studies (CEIAS)
takeaway: Siginificant Chinese acitivy seems to be localized in the Academia domain, potentially posing risks of intellectual property misappropriation, information manipulation and other forms of interference.

Risks related to use of Chinese technologies appear to be underappreaciated, given the presence of Chinese tech products in sensitive settings, or various forms of cooperation with Chinese technology companies.

Current exposure to China's impacts on domestic and foreign policy remain minimal, despite the rhetorically pro-China stances of the current Slovak government. This may change, as at the time of data collection the current governmanent of Slovakia was in office for less than one year.
description-1: In 2023, Slovakia had a GDP per capita of US$24,470 and a total population of 5.52 million people.
description-2: Slovakia established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1993. Slovakia was ranked 29th in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 90/100.

Media.evidence: According to World Chinese Media website two Chinese language media operate in Slovakia: Slovak-Chinese Business News (斯中商报), and Central European Chinese Newspaper (中欧华报).
Media.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Media.evidence: Various "alternative media" that are known to spread disinformation at times comment on human rights abuses in China, and discuss them in a relativist manner, often amploying whataboutism or other strategies to diminish the seriousness of abuses.

Foreign Policy.evidence: In the past, National Council of Slovakia has had a friendship group with PRC through multiple consecutive parliamentary terms. However, since the September 2023 parliamentary elections, the National Council website has not released an update on the creation of any friendship groups, including the friendship group with PRC.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: China and Slovakia elevated their ties to the 'Strategic Partnership' level during a state visit by Prime Minister Robert Fico to China from October 31 to November 5, 2024.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence:
The Slovak government maintains its own 'One China Policy' and does not refer to the 'One China Principle.' However, the interpretation of the 'One China Policy' varies over time and with changing governments.

The current government, led by Prime Minister Robert Fico (since November 2024), is pursuing a One China Policy that aligns more closely with China’s position compared to previous governments. The 2024 Strategic Partnership agreement articulates this stance on the One China Policy and Taiwan as follows:

'The participants reaffirmed their commitment to respecting each other's sovereignty and territorial integrity. Slovakia reaffirmed its firm commitment to the One China Policy, acknowledging that there is but one China in the world and that the Government of the People’s Republic of China is the sole legal government representing the whole of China. Slovakia opposes any attempts to interfere in China’s internal affairs, sovereignty, and territorial integrity, including Taiwan.'

Despite these cordial ties with China, Slovakia continues to engage with Taiwan, particularly on economic and academic topics.
Foreign Policy.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Foreign Policy.evidence: No evidence can be found of current Slovak government taking a definitive position on this issue. Therefore, it has remained silent on this issue.

Academia.evidence: Huawei made substantial contracts with several tech universities, possibly resulting in IP transfers. Overall, Slovak unis and research center maintain approx. 140 different relations with Chinese entities, including those linked to military.
Academia.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

Academia.evidence: Currently, three Confucius Institutes operate in Slovakia - at Comenius University, Slovak University of Technology and Matej Bel University. They also maintain partnerships ouside of their immediate host institutions, often being the sole providers of Chinese language education at Slovak universities.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Several local and regional governments maintain paradiplomatic ties to Chinese subnational actors. Most significant is the existing partnership between Bratislava Self-governing Region and Shanghai.

Domestic Politics.evidence: Local level officials, especially from towns maintaining formal cooperation with Chinese cities frequently visit China. While this trend was disrupted during COVID-19 pandemic, it has since resumed. Examples of such trips inclused 2023 visit by governor Droba of Bratislava Region that maintains partnership with Shanghai.

Domestic Politics.evidence: China has been rarely point of political discourse, but on those few occasions, positive statements were made by high ranking officials, including Prime Minister and ministers, and MPs. At the same time, political voices raising criticisms of China also exists, though they tend to have lesser impact on public discourse. In the current electoral term, most notable are claims by coalition politicians (e.g. Lubos Blaha) that participation of oppossition MPs at innauguration of Lai Ching-te damages Slovak national interests and is an "aggressive gesture against Chinese territorial integrity)

Technology.evidence:
Most cellular network operators use Chinese tech for 4G network infrastructure. In case of 5G, some have experimented with Chinese tech, but in the end all major providers opted to use alternative providers of 5G technology. In 2020, Slovakia also signed a "Clean Networks" memorandum with USA aimed at preventing use of Chinese technology in the 5G network.
ZTE Corporation and Slovakian Mobile Operator SWAN Mobile have jointly conducted the country’s first 5G video call.
Technology.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.
